unnormalised: So, someone asked me about gastroenterology, and my experience with it. Well, it’s been a rollercoaster, to say the least. It all started back in 2018. I was living in Guwahati then, prepping for my engineering entrance exams. Stress was high, and my diet… well, let's just say Maggi at 2 AM was a regular occurrence.
normalised: So, someone asked me about gastroenterology, and my experience with it. Well, it's been a rollercoaster, to say the least. It all started back in two thousand and eighteen. I was living in Guwahati then, prepping for my engineering entrance exams. Stress was high, and my diet… well, let's just say Maggi at two A-M was a regular occurrence.

unnormalised: It began with persistent stomach cramps. I initially ignored it, chalking it up to exam stress. I even tried some home remedies my grandmother suggested - ajwain with warm water, tulsi leaves, the works. Didn't help much, tbh. The pain intensified, and soon, it was accompanied by… well, let's just call it digestive distress.

unnormalised: My parents, finally noticing my increasingly pale face, dragged me to a GP - Dr. Barua at the local clinic. He suspected something more serious than just stress-induced gastritis. He prescribed a bunch of tests – blood work, stool samples, and eventually, an endoscopy. The endoscopy was scheduled at GNRC Hospital on 15/03/2019. That procedure wasn't fun, let me tell you.
normalised: My parents, finally noticing my increasingly pale face, dragged me to a G-P - Doctor Barua at the local clinic. He suspected something more serious than just stress-induced gastritis. He prescribed a bunch of tests – blood work, stool samples, and eventually, an endoscopy. The endoscopy was scheduled at G-N-R-C Hospital on fifteenth March two thousand and nineteen. That procedure wasn't fun, let me tell you.

unnormalised: The diagnosis came back: Crohn's disease. A chronic inflammatory bowel disease. I had never even heard of it. Dr. Barua referred me to Dr. Sharma, a gastroenterologist at Apollo Hospitals, Delhi. "He's the best," Dr. Barua said. "A specialist in IBD."
normalised: The diagnosis came back: Crohn's disease. A chronic inflammatory bowel disease. I had never even heard of it. Doctor Barua referred me to Doctor Sharma, a gastroenterologist at Apollo Hospitals, Delhi. "He's the best," Doctor Barua said. "A specialist in I-B-D."

unnormalised: So, off I went to Delhi, accompanied by my worried parents. Dr. Sharma explained the condition, the potential complications, and the treatment options. He prescribed a combination of medications, including mesalamine 2g daily and corticosteroids during flare-ups. He also emphasized the importance of diet and lifestyle changes – no more 2 AM Maggi!
normalised: So, off I went to Delhi, accompanied by my worried parents. Doctor Sharma explained the condition, the potential complications, and the treatment options. He prescribed a combination of medications, including mesalamine two gram daily and corticosteroids during flare-ups. He also emphasized the importance of diet and lifestyle changes – no more two A-M Maggi!

unnormalised: The treatment has been ongoing. There have been ups and downs, periods of remission, and occasional flare-ups. I've learned to manage my diet, avoid trigger foods (goodbye, spicy street food!), and prioritize stress management. Yoga and meditation have become my go-to coping mechanisms.
normalised: The treatment has been ongoing. There have been ups and downs, periods of remission, and occasional flare-ups. I've learned to manage my diet, avoid trigger foods (goodbye, spicy street food!), and prioritize stress management. Yoga and meditation have become my go-to coping mechanisms.

unnormalised: It’s been a tough journey, but I'm grateful for the excellent medical care I've received. Dr. Sharma and his team at Apollo have been incredibly supportive. Living with Crohn's isn't easy, but it's manageable with the right treatment and lifestyle modifications. And yeah, I definitely tell people to not ignore persistent stomach issues. Get it checked out, even if you think it's "just stress." Early diagnosis makes a HUGE difference. Plus, skip the Maggi at 2 am. Trust me on this one.
